| Stage of Development | Number of Compounds Entering Stage | Number of Compounds Failing Stage | Main Reason for Failure |

questions.question_stem:
A professional free-diver performs a timed dive. Scientists record physiological data before the dive and immediately after the diver resurfaces.


**Table 2** shows some of the data collected.


**Table 2**


| Parameter                               | Before Dive (at rest) | Immediately After Resurfacing |
|-----------------------------------------|-----------------------:|------------------------------:|
| Blood pH                                |                   7.4  |                           7.1 |
| Muscle Glycogen concentration (arb. u.) |                    85  |                            45 |
| Blood Lactate concentration (mmol/dm³)  |                   1.2  |                          14.2 |
| Breathing Rate (breaths per minute)     |                    12  |                            48 |

items.question_text: Explain why the diver's breathing rate remains high for several minutes after resurfacing. Use information from **Table 2**.

•(anaerobic respiration produces) lactic acid/lactate (1)

•(extra) oxygen is needed to break down the lactic acid (1)

•Repay oxygen debt (1)

items.question_text: Calculate the percentage decrease in the diver's muscle glycogen concentration. Show your working.
items.markscheme:
(decrease =) 85 - 45 (= 40) (1)

(40 / 85 x 100 =) 47.1 (%) (1)

allow 47 (%)
allow correct answer for 2 marks, even without working

items.question_text: Give two pieces of evidence from **Table 2** that suggest the diver's muscle cells respired anaerobically.

Any two from:
• blood lactate / lactic acid increases (from 1.2 to 14.2) (1)
• muscle glycogen decreases (showing glucose has been used up for respiration) (1)
• blood pH decreases / blood becomes more acidic (1)

(low pH / high acidity) denatures enzymes (1)

allow (this) slows down / stops metabolic reactions
allow named examples of metabolic reactions

items.question_text: What is the word equation for anaerobic respiration in muscle cells?
items.markscheme:
glucose $\rightarrow$ lactic acid (1)

ignore (+ little energy)

questions.question_stem:
A commercial grower uses large greenhouses to grow tomatoes. 

To maximise the growth rate of the tomato plants, the grower can increase the concentration of carbon dioxide inside the greenhouses. However, carbon dioxide is costly.

The grower wants to find the most cost-effective concentration of carbon dioxide to use. 
They decide to use pondweed in a model system to investigate the effect of carbon dioxide concentration on the rate of photosynthesis.

items.question_text:
In this question you will be assessed on using good English, organising information clearly and using specialist terms where appropriate.

Describe a method to investigate the effect of carbon dioxide concentration on the rate of photosynthesis.

You should include details of:
• how you would set up the apparatus and the materials you would use
• the measurements you would make
• how you could make this a fair test.
items.markscheme:
Marks awarded for this answer will be determined by the Quality of Written Communication (QWC) as well as the standard of the scientific response. Examiners should apply a ‘best-fit’ approach to the marking.

**0 marks**
No relevant content.

**Level 1 (1–2 marks)**
A partial description of a method. A few steps are attempted, but the description is unclear or lacks detail. May identify the independent variable ($CO_2$) or dependent variable (bubbles/gas) or a single control variable.

**Level 2 (3–4 marks)**
A description of a method with some logical steps. Describes how to vary the $CO_2$ concentration (e.g. using sodium hydrogencarbonate) AND how to measure the rate of photosynthesis. At least one variable is identified as needing to be controlled.

**Level 3 (5–6 marks)**
A clear, logical, and detailed description of a method. It explains how the $CO_2$ concentration will be varied systematically, how the rate will be measured accurately, and how key variables will be controlled to ensure a fair test. For full marks, the method must be fully repeatable and include specific details on controlling both temperature and light intensity.

**Examples of biology points made in the response:**
• **Apparatus set up:** place a piece of pondweed in a beaker of water / sodium hydrogencarbonate solution.
• **Varying the independent variable:** use different concentrations / masses of sodium hydrogencarbonate (e.g. 0.2 g, 0.4 g etc.) in a fixed volume of water.
• **Controlling variables:**
    – **Temperature:** use a thermostatically controlled water bath or a heat shield between the lamp and beaker and monitor with a thermometer.
    – **Light intensity:** place an LED lamp a fixed distance from the beaker.
    – **Plant:** use the same piece of pondweed for each test, or sprigs of the same length/mass.
• **Procedure:** leave the pondweed for a period of time (e.g. 5 minutes) to acclimatise to the new conditions before taking measurements.
• **Measuring dependent variable:** count the number of bubbles produced in a set time (e.g. 1 minute) OR collect the gas produced in an inverted measuring cylinder / gas syringe and measure the volume over a set time (e.g. 10 minutes).
• **Rate calculation:** rate of photosynthesis = volume of gas produced / time taken.
• **Reliability:** repeat the experiment at least three times for each concentration and calculate a mean.

questions.question_stem:
A scientist investigated the effect of rooting powder on the growth of new roots from cuttings of a valuable plant. 

The rooting powder contains the plant hormone auxin.

The scientist:
• took 200 cuttings from the same parent plant
• dipped the base of 40 cuttings into one of five powders (each with a different concentration of auxin).
• used one powder as a control and contained no auxin
• planted each cutting into a pot containing the same type volume of compost
• placed the pots in a propagator for 3 weeks
• recorded the percentage of cuttings that had successfully grown roots.

**Table 2** below shows the results.

items.description: Uploaded PNG diagram: Screenshot 2025-09-12 at 11.58.39 am.png

items.question_text:
In this question you will be assessed on using good English, organising information clearly and using specialist terms where appropriate.

Describe how a plant shoot and a plant root respond to the environmental factors of light and gravity.

In your answer you should refer to the role of auxin.
items.markscheme:
Level 3 (5–6 marks):
A detailed and coherent description of responses to both light and gravity for both shoots and roots. The role of auxin in causing differential growth is explained clearly for both shoots and roots.

Level 2 (3–4 marks):
A description of at least one tropism for a shoot and a root, with some reference to auxin. Or a detailed description of tropisms in shoots and roots with a limited or partially correct explanation of the hormonal role.

Level 1 (1–2 marks):
A simple statement about a plant response, e.g., 'shoots grow to light'. Auxin is named as a hormone. The information is basic and may be poorly organised.

0 marks:
No relevant content.

Examples of biology points made in the response:
•	shoots grow towards light / are positively phototropic
•	shoots grow away from gravity / are negatively gravitropic
•	roots grow away from light / are negatively phototropic
•	roots grow towards gravity / are positively gravitropic
•	auxin is a plant hormone that controls growth
•	auxin is produced in the tips (of shoots/roots)
•	(in response to light) auxin diffuses to the shaded side of the shoot tip
•	this leads to unequal distribution of auxin
•	(in shoots) higher concentration of auxin causes increased cell elongation/growth
•	(in response to gravity) auxin concentrates on the lower side of the root/shoot
•	(in roots) a high concentration of auxin inhibits cell elongation/growth

items.question_text: Give one reason why it was important to use cuttings from the same parent plant.
items.markscheme:
any one from:
•	to control for genetic factors
•	so they are genetically identical / have the same genes / have the same DNA
•	so that any difference in rooting is due to the auxin concentration (and not genetics)

ignore 'to make it a fair test' without qualification

items.question_text: Explain why the scientist used a powder with a concentration of 0 mg/kg of auxin.
items.markscheme:
any one from:
•	as a control
•	for comparison / to compare the results to
•	to see what happens without (added) auxin / to see if auxin has an effect

do not allow 'as a control variable'

items.question_text:
The scientist concluded that a concentration of 300 mg/kg was the most effective to use for commercial purposes.

Suggest how the data in **Table 2** supports this conclusion.
items.markscheme:
it gives the highest percentage of cuttings with roots (at 90%)

allow it is the optimum concentration
allow it gives the most rooted cuttings

items.question_text: Suggest one reason why the percentage of cuttings forming roots decreased when the concentration was increased to 400 mg/kg.
items.markscheme:
(a high) concentration of auxin inhibits root growth

allow it is toxic / harmful at high concentrations
allow it has passed the optimum concentration

A conservation team is estimating the population of limpets on a specific 200 m² section of a rocky shore. A large limpet population is an indicator of good water quality.

A junior member of the team carried out a preliminary survey. They placed five 0.5 m × 0.5 m quadrats on the lower part of the shore, near the water line, because limpets were abundant there.


**Table 4** below shows the results.


Based on these results, the junior conservationist estimated the total limpet population in the 200 m² area to be 9600.


**Table 4**

questions.question_stem:
**Figure 1** shows a simplified map of two valleys in the Alps. Mountain Avens are a species of plant found in both valleys.

Scientists believe the two populations were originally one, but were separated for thousands of years by a glacier. The plants in Valley A now have slightly different shaped leaves and flower colours compared to the plants in Valley B.

items.question_text: Explain how the population of Mountain Avens in Valley A could have become different from the population in Valley B.
items.markscheme:
• (separate populations have) genetic variation / different alleles / there are mutations (1)
• different environmental conditions / selection pressures in each valley (1)
  allow a specific example e.g. different soil minerals / pollinators
• (in each population) individuals with advantageous alleles/features survive and reproduce (1)
  allow ‘survival of the fittest’
• so these (advantageous) alleles are passed on to the next generation (1)

items.question_text:
Scientists now believe the two populations of Mountain Avens are two different species.

Describe the evidence scientists would need to collect to confirm this.
items.markscheme:
any two from:
• cross-pollinate plants from the two populations (1)
• show that they do not produce fertile offspring (1)
  allow cannot produce viable seeds
• analysis of DNA / genes shows significant differences (1)

items.question_text:
A species of bird that acts as a pollinator for the Mountain Avens is now able to fly between the two valleys.

Suggest what effect this could have on the future evolution of these plant populations.
items.markscheme:
• gene flow occurs / pollen/genes/alleles are transferred between the populations (1)
• this could lead to interbreeding, reducing differences between the populations (1)
  allow it could slow down / reverse speciation
